results.title: The Pacific
results.brief_description: A history of the Pacific Ocean from earliest times. Animated diagrams, maps and charts are used to tell the story.

results.title: The Pace that thrills
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardner and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: A short review of some of Britain’s leading track athletes in action. Gordon Pirie, Mary Bignall Rand and Peter Radford demonstrate the correct methods of starting, sprinting, long-distance running and hurdling.

results.title: The Pace that kills
results.brief_description: Excessive speed is the number one killer on the roads: one-thrid of all road deaths are caused by it. By excessive speeding drivers risk their own lives and those of others.

results.title: The Owl who married a goose: an Eskimo legend
results.creator_credit: Caroline Leaf, Pierre Moretti and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: An Eskimo legend of a goose that captures the fancy of an owl. Although the voices are in Inuktitut Caroline Leaf’s innovative animation leave no doubt as to the happenings that transpire. It is a story with wry humour characteristic of many Inuit tales, for audiences young and old. Editing, Pierre Lemelin. (Eight awards, including Oscar nomination, Hollywood.)
results.title_for_label: The Owl who married a goose: an Eskimo legend

results.title: The Owl and the pussy-cat
results.creator_credit: John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: Edward Lear’s nonsense poem tells the love story of the owl and the pussycat who sailed together to the land where the Bong-tree grows; there they married, ate wonderful food and danced by the light of the moon. This fantasy comes to life in Halas’ cartoon with the verses sung by Maurice Bevan. Animation: Vic Bevis, Reg Lodge. Suitable for lower primary school level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films

results.title: The Owl and the lemming: an eskimo legend (K)
results.creator_credit: Co Hoedeman, Pierre Moretti and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The owl and the lemming in this animated film are short-legged, plumply stuffed puppets made of seal skin by Inuit artists. The accompanying song and voices are in Inuktitut, although the legend is narrated in English. It is a story that all audiences, especially children, will enjoy. Moreover, it preserves on film an example of Inuit folklore they may in time disappear.

results.title: The Owl and the lemming: an eskimo legend
results.creator_credit: Co Hoedeman, Pierre Moretti and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The owl and the lemming in this animated film are short-legged, plumpy stuffed puppets made of seal skin by Inuit artists. The accompanying song and voices are in Inuktitut, although the legend is narrated in English. The story in which an owl hunts a lemming will appeal to all audiences, especially children. Moreover, it preserves on film an example of Inuit folklore that may in time disappear.

results.title: The Owl and Fred Jones
results.creator_credit: Denis Gilpin, Ed Cullen, Equitable Life Assurance Society and W.M. Larkins Studio
results.brief_description: An explanation of how we can control our habits and make them serve us. Fred Jones realises his behaviour is a series of habits - some good, some bad. He would like to change some, like over-eating, but never bothered to try. The owl convinces him that if you want to, if you know how, and if you’re willing to work at it, habits can be changed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Denis Gilpin, Ed Cullen, Equitable Life Assurance Society and W.M. Larkins Studio

results.title: The Outsider
results.brief_description: Poses the problem of a girl who, through psychological inhibition, feels cut off from normal, friendly social relations with her school-fellows. Briefly shows how she tends to behave as an isolated individual; how other children distrust and resent her. Another girl tries to understand her difficulties, gives her the opportunity of mixing with the group. The film is stated in simple terms, addressed to secondary school level.

results.title: The Outsider
results.creator_credit: Barry Washington and Country Education Project
results.brief_description: Richard McRoberts and Gary Kinnance begin the discussion with a brief survey of Albert Camus’ life and philosophy to set a background for a fuller treatment of the book. Specific passages are used as springboards for the analysis and explication of Camus’ themes. The meaning and place of “The Outsiders” as a piece of existential literature is discussed.
